coredata.dc:title: Isotope effect on the melting of para-hydrogen and ortho-deuterium clusters
coredata.dc:creator: Scharf, Daphna
Martyna, Glenn J.
Klein, Michael L.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Path integral Monte Carlo calculations have been used to investigate the isotope effect on the “melting” of small clusters of para-hydrogen (p-H2) and ortho-deuterium (o-D2). While clusters of (o-D2) N with N=13 and 55 exhibit a quantum-lipid→quantum-solid “freezing” transition in a temperature regime where the effects of Bose statistics are unimportant, the corresponding (p-H2) N clusters do not.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 197, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 11 September 1992 Isotope effect on the melting of para-hydrogen and ortho-deuterium clusters Daphna Scharf, Glenn J. Martyna and Michael L. Klein Department of Chemistry, University ofPennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA 19104-6323, USA Received 18 June 1992 Path integral Monte Carlo calculations have been used to investigate the isotope effect on the "melting" of small clusters of para-hydrogen (p-HZ) and ortho-deuterium (o-DZ). While clusters of (o-Dz)N with N=13 and 55 exhibit a quantumlipid-quantum-solid "freezing" transition in a temperature regime where the effects of Bose statistics are unimportant, the corresponding (p-HZ)N clusters do not. 1. Introduction Phase transitions in clusters are, to a large extent, still beyond direct experimental observation, yet theories, models and simulations based on classical mechanics have related melting to a rigid- non-rigid transition. The characterization of this transition is by a jump in the caloric curve, the identification of coexistence of solid-like and liquid-like regimes, the appearance of a soft mode and large amplitude fluctuations in the bond distances [ 1-8 ] . The extent to which quantum effects modify this transition in raregas clusters has been thoroughly investigated [ 9,10 ] . In small Ne clusters, the transition temperature was found to be shifted to lower temperatures, but otherwise in qualitative agreement with the results based on classical calculations [ 10 ] . Much closer agreement between quantum and classical calculations was found for (Ar)N, except at very low temperatures where the effect of the zero-point energy becomes evident [9,10]. Extreme quantum character has been predicted for 'He clusters [ 11-17 ]. Quantum path-integral Monte Carlo calculations not only suggest a low temperature superfluid-like regime for ("He)64, but also a clear remnant of the A, transition persisting for clus- Correspondence to: M.L. Klein, Department of Chemistry, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA 19104-6323, USA. 0009-2614/92/$ 05.00 1992 Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. All rights reserved. ters as small as ('He),2$ [ 17 ]. Such clusters should, therefore, lack magic numbers and high-symmetry structures even at T=0 K [11-13]. For molecular hydrogen, the thermal de Broglie wavelength, 4=4/ (mkBT) `12, is only a little smaller than that of 4He. Thus, in the temperature regime appropriate to clusters produced in a molecular beam, .lth is a significant fraction of the intermolecular separation. Hence, the extent to which quantum effects modify the properties of clusters of molecular hydrogen, and its isotopes, deuterium and tritium, is intriguing [ 1822 ] . A recent path-integral Monte Carlo study of low temperature p-142 clusters suggests that quantum effects are very important. In particular, a low temperature superfluid-like regime has been predicted to occur for (p-Hz )N clusters when N;!S 20, even though bulk HZ is a solid for T< 13.8 K [ 19 ] . In this article we compare and contrast the behaviour of (o-DZ)N clusters with the more quantum (p-H2) N clusters. On the basis of the calculated rms fluctuations in the intermolecular separation we confirm a striking isotope effect on the "melting" transition of small clusters of p-HZ and o-D2. While small clusters of (o-DZ)N with N=13 and 55 exhibit a quantum-solid-.quantum-liquid transition around 4 K, the corresponding (p-HZ) N clusters do not [ 21 ] . The results of the present article may be useful in guiding future experiments of the type currently being carried out for 'He clusters [ 14,15 ] . 231 Volume 197, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 1 I September 1992 2. Path integral Monte Carlo calculations In order to study the mass effect on properties of small molecular-hydrogen clusters we have employed the Feynman path integral Monte Carlo technique along with the Pollock-Ceperley staging algorithm [ 23 ] . Since we focus on differences between hydrogen and deuterium we will be mostly interested in a temperature regime where the effects associated with Bose statistics are unimportant [ 24 ] '. We have employed the semi-empirical SilveraGoldman intermolecular potential [ 25 ] . A number of other semi-empirical potentials have been proposed for the isotropic (spherical) part of the hydrogen potential [25-28]. They were developed using various approaches including ab initio calculations [ 28 ], solid- and liquid-phase data [ 25,27 ] , and gas-phase scattering data [ 26 ] . Based on the equation-of-state in the solid phase, Silvera and Goldman [25] proposed a potential for solid molecular hydrogen (p-HZ) and deuterium (o-D2). The potential consists of a sum of a pair potential term and a many-body part, which is approximated by the Axilrod-Teller-Muto triple dipole interaction. Compared with the other potentials, this potential shows good overall agreement with a number of experimental properties under normal as well as moderately high pressures [ 25,29 ] . In this work we lave chosen to use the Silvera-Goldman potential for two main reasons. First, the use of a spherical effective pair potential enables direct comparison of pHz with o-Dz without worrying about differences in intramolecular bond lengths, molecular polarizabilities, etc. Second, it enabled us to relate our results to the previous study of (p-HZ)N clusters [21 ]. For reference, the well depth, E, of the Silvera-Goldman effective pair potential is 32.2 K. We have characterized the isotope mass effect on molecular-hydrogen clusters according to the following calculated temperature-dependent properties derived from the path integral calculations: (a) the energetics of the clusters, (b) structural properties such as normalized density profiles and radial distribution func- $0' Ceperley and Pollock demonstrated the effect of Bose statistics on pair distribution functions to be small in the case of liquid "He at 2.0 K; the effect should be even smaller for hydrogen clusters. 232 tions, (c) root-mean-square (rms) fluctuations in the averaged intermolecular bond distance, o, and (d) the gyration radius and rms deviations in the averaged position. The main results of the path integral calculations are summarized in table 1 for clusters with N-13 and in table 2 for N-55. The Table 1 Mass effect on the properties of molecular-hydrogen clusters with N=13. All energies are per molecule of Hz (DZ). Error bars are the rms standard deviations between sets of averages. Volume 197, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 11 September 1992 reported results were generated by averaging over an extensive sampling of the configuration space. Following equilibration, we have generated sequences of 2.5 X 105 cluster configurations at temperatures away from the transition region. Much longer sequences of (5.0-7.5) X 105 configurations were generated near the transition. We have used a discretization parameter P=128 for the number of points along the Feynman path describing each HZ (DZ) molecule in the system. With this number points, convergence is attained for the HZ clusters to within the estimated inaccuracy of the calculated energies. In the implementation of the staging algorithm [ 23 ] we used values ranging from 0.6-1.1 au (0.65-1.25 ) for the center-of-mass moves for HZ (Dz). The segment of the path moved ranged from 10 to 28 points (12-45) for HZ (DZ). The acceptance ratio was always ~ 40%. In the classical Monte Carlo runs, we have generated up to 1.5 X 106 configurations close to the transition region. Coarse grain averaging was performed over sets of 2.5 X 10 configurations away from the transition region and over 5.0 X 10 configurations near the transition region. The quantity, Te, listed in the tables is bounded by the highest temperature for which no evaporation events were found and the temperature for which at least a single dissociation was encountered in three independent runs. The dramatic isotope effect on the quantum character of molecular-hydrogen clusters can be demonstrated most vividly by examining quantities dependent on spatial fluctuations. We have calculated the temperature dependence of the rms bond-length fluctuations in (p-HZ)N and (o-D2)N clusters. At a given temperature the rms fluctuation is defined by _ 2 <ri_<t;i)2 a N(N-1) ~ <r0 where the brackets indicate averaging over configuration space, and r;; is the distance between the ith and the jth hydrogen molecules. Previous quantum and classical simulations for Lennard-Jones clusters have identified a rapid rise in 8 with the cluster rigid-.non-rigid melting transition [ 10 ] . For o-D2 clusters we find qualitatively similar behavior (see figs. 1 and 2) but the a values in (p-H2) N clusters present a different picture. Our present results, combined with previous low temperature data that included the effects of Bose statistics [ 21 ], con- T' 0.0 0.1 0.2 0.3 0.4 0.4 0.3- &0 0.2~- 0.1- o.ol 0 4 6 8 10 12 T (K) Fig. 1. The asterisks ( (p-H2)13 ) have been taken from ref. [21 ] and include the effect of Bose statistics. The reduced temperature, T"=kBt/e, is also given. The reduced temperature, T'-kBT/E, is also given. firm that small (p-HZ)N clusters are fluxional at all temperatures. For larger clusters in the temperature regime where the effect of permutations on the wavefunction are important (i.e. below T-2 K) the present calculations yield a slightly over-localized state [ 24 ] ( see footnote 1) . Hence, for p-HZ clusters, the rms fluctuations calculated without permuta- 233 Volume 197, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 11 September 1992 tions are likely a lower bound on the actual value (see figs. 1 and 2 ). The calculated 8 values always range around 20% for (p-H2)N in pronounced contrast to the values for (o-D2)N. While the former are quantum-liquid like, with no freezing being exhibited, for (o-D2)N we found a transition at T-4 K#2. This freezing transition occurs at much lower temperature than the classical counterpart, as is demonstrated in figs. 1 and 2. The latter results were obtained by employing the same interaction potential, [ 25 ], but classical Monte Carlo simulations. The present calculations confirm that a corresponding classical cluster will undergo a transition similar to that found for the quantum counterpart when a comparable value of 8 is attained [ 10 ] . The main difference is in the value of the transition temperatures. For (o-DAN clusters the transition is also apparent in the normalized density profiles shown in fig. 3, which compares the low- and high-temperature profiles for (o-D2 )13 with the T- 2. 5 K result for (pH2)i3- Non-rigidity in quantum clusters is closely associated with spatial permutations involving more than three particles [17,23]. Such "motions" cause the #Z In fig. 2, at low T, the 8 values for (o-D2)55 exhibit a small hump between 2.5 and 4.25 K which does not seem to reflect inaccuracy of the calculations. We suspect that this signals a configurational transformation, such as surface melting, and we are in the process of investigating this possibility. 0.10, 0.0s- 0.06 Q 0.04 o z 0.02 0.00- 0 2 4 r (A Fig. 3. Normalized radial density profiles for various N=13 hydrogen clusters: The bold curve is for (p-HZ),3, at T-2.5 K, the dotted and dashed curves are for (o-D2),3 at T=2.5 K and T=6.0 K, respectively. The non-zero value of the bold curve around 2 A for p-HZ should be noted (see text). 234 structural profiles to appear smeared and finite val ues are exhibited in the density profile at distance values between the major peaks. This signature of non-rigidity is exhibited by the density profile of (p Hz ) , 3 at all temperatures. For ( o-D2 (o-D2)13 at T=2.5 K the zero values for the density profile at rx 2 A in dicates freezing of the central atom in the structure and the suppression of its participation in spatial permutations. Similar findings prevail for the N- 55 clusters. Our study of the growth sequence and sta bility of p-HZ clusters has been published elsewhere [30]. 3. Conclusions Quantum path integral Monte Carlo calculations reported herein reinforce the notion that small clusters of hydrogen molecules will exhibit extreme quantum behavior [ 21 ] . The calculated rms bond length fluctuations 8, such as shown in figs. 1 and 2, and structural profiles, such as shown in fig. 3, have been used to characterize the behavior of small clusters of p-H2 and o-D2 in a temperature regime where the effects of Bose statistics are relatively unimportant ( i.e. T> 2 K ) [ 24 ] . In the case of o-D2, we find a transformation from quantum "solid" to quantum "liquid" at T=4 K when 8~ 10 r6-15 r6. The transition temperature is significantly lower than the corresponding classical one. Small p-H2 clusters behave very differently in that for N=13, in the temperature range T > 2 K, the values of 8 never fall below x 0.2. Such clusters are, therefore, still liquid-like at this temperature and hence exhibit extreme quantum behavior. The present calculations complement and reinforce the conclusions of a previous study that focused on the effect of Bose statistics at even lower temperatures [21 ]. Clearly, in view of the predicted extreme quantum behavior, small hydrogen clusters will be worthy of experimental study and we understand such experiments are being attempted [ 15 ] . Acknowledgement We thank Steve Rodgers, Giacinto Scoles and Peter Toennies for their interest in our work. ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Path integral Monte Carlo calculations have been used to investigate the isotope effect on the “melting” of small clusters of para-hydrogen (p-H2) and ortho-deuterium (o-D2). While clusters of (o-D2) N with N=13 and 55 exhibit a quantum-lipid→quantum-solid “freezing” transition in a temperature regime where the effects of Bose statistics are unimportant, the corresponding (p-H2) N clusters do not.
